title: why are players not instanty suspened for telling someone to kys?
body: I've been told to kill myself about 100 times in the last month on league.  just wondering.  Almost no words in English include kys in them... should be pretty easy to automate.

replies.body: That's pretty dumb. I get that we are all tired of toxicity, but having someone immediately being banned for saying kys is a little extreme.

Besides before suicide people usually arent doing much. Its not like "Welp im gonna have a fun game of league with my trusty noose next to me just in case."

If you are THAT much in distress where "kys" on an online game, pushes you overboard you SHOULDNT be playing any multiplayer games ever. At least not until you get some help.

My biggest issue is you cant make videogames a safety bunker because SHITTY people exist. The only way to remove "kys" and variations are just by not allowing chat AT ALL, hell maybe not even communication in general.

EDIT: To reiterate, my issue isnt this idea, its the idea that this will actually help anything. suicide is a large issue, but making an online game not allow you to say "kys" Is a waste of time that affects no one, people dont kill themselves for someone saying "kys" Now if someone said "Fuck you you worthless jungler, i bet you contribute as meaningfully to society as much as you do to our lanes" That MIGHT have an affect on someones well-being (even then they still should get help if they are in that dire straights)

Look, it may not be the cause, but possibly it could contribute. And even if it is not do we really want to accept this as okay? I agree that kys and the probability of it being a contributing factor is next to impossible to prove, but  there are many examples of online bullying that contribute to someone's suicide. If it can be eliminated then why not try?

Hey, if there's a good way to cut down on online bullying, I'm all in favor of that! I don't think censoring particular phrases is necessarily the best approach, but I suppose it might conceivably help at least a little bit.

On the other hand, If we're talking about "kys" as though it has some special power to actually make people kill themselves, I think that's wrong and misguided. Telling people to kill themselves is nasty and horrible, but it doesn't threaten lives above and beyond any other nasty and horrible thing people might say to each other, of which there are many.

The term "kys" is now kinda League/gaming culture. If you've noticed that a lot of people and pros will say "kms" "kys" when shit happens. At first it kinda irritated me but now it's just like saying "fuck you".

A lot of responses to my original post.  more than i would expect.

A few things to make points about
1) I personally do not care is people want me to die.  But it is not unreasonable to believe others do.  I have concern for those players.
2) Muting the team/all preemptively isn't really a good option.  As one can see from the poorly thought out support singed logic the Riot has put  on the forums (but nowhere in the actual rules)  If you get reported for making others feel they had a bad in game experience they will say you didn't communicate some form of your playstyle and suspend / delete your account.
3) even if you mute everyone 3-8 other people in the game can get tied up with people telling others to kill themselves.  The message is still sent to your team or all chat regardless of if you see it.



It will be a sad, unfortunate, but interesting day when someone in the LOL community actually does kill themselves and cites league players telling them to. (among other things i would believe)  Riot is opening themselves up to a gross/willful negligence lawsuit by not keeping the community up to the standards or the AUP and summoners code.  Possibly even more, depending what country it occurs and what laws they have on internet companies regulating hate speech on electronic platforms.

It is more than clear Riot gives players way to many chances at "being toxic" than they should be allowed to be.

By the time Riot gets around to actually punishing people they believe their behavior is allowed.
